title: THE ILLUSION OF SUCCESS Part 3
scripture_text: The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” He replied, I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven. I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”
devotional:
In critiquing the ministry of the seventy/seventy two Jesus helped them see a wider perspective. They had power over demons, but Jesus saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven. In other words, what they experienced and saw was not the whole picture, there were things that were related to their victory over demons that they had no knowledge or understanding of.

Success was never meant to become a source of Joy.

Jesus’ perspective in what the seventy/seventy two said.

The first thing Jesus says to these returning disciples is ‘I saw Satan fall like lighting from heaven’’

When did Jesus see this happen?

Interpreters are divided. Was it the moment Satan rebelled and God cast him out of heaven? Was it the moment Jesus was conceived with the express purpose of conquering Satan? Was it when Jesus defeated Satan in the wilderness? Or maybe Jesus was looking to the future, to the cross where he would crush Satan once and for all. Any and all of those may be true. But the point is not when it happened, but how? The disciples were overjoyed that they were able to drive out demons in Jesus’ name. That’s the key in this context. Jesus is telling disciples at all times that wherever and whenever His name is proclaimed, Satan falls from power, he loses his control, he is defeated.

This is both encouraging and helpful. As far as Jesus is concerned, Spiritual warfare is Gods initiative. These seventy/seventy two saw the kingdom of darkness overcome when they went on mission.

It is concerning, that for most part, Christians have a negative understanding of Spiritual warfare; they solely understand it as Satan attacking them, or the church. And that does and will happen. Possibly one of the reasons for this common negative perspective on spiritual warfare is because the vast majority of bible teachers understand Paul’s teaching on the armour of God in Ephesians 6:10-20 as being defensive, however, the only place a Roman solider would wear his full armour was when he was going on to the battlefield, where he would engage with his enemy.

The fact that Spiritual warfare is initiated by God does not mean that it is easy or less stressful. There are four main exorcisms in Mark's Gospel. They are the man in the Capernaum synagogue (Mark 1:21-27), the man possessed by "Legion" in the region of Gerasa (Mark 5:1-20), the daughter of the Syrophoenician woman (Mark 7:24-30), and the boy with the "dumb spirit" (Mark 9:14-29). All these four exorcisms have a common feature, Jesus went to where the demon was. Jesus was taking the battle to them.

We often think that we’re doing something right because Satan is attacking us, but if you were really were to think about this, in saying this we are unwittingly getting our affirmation from the activity of Satan, which is never a good thing. Also we are creating the false comfort that comes from having a victim mindset. Perhaps a better way to think is to see spiritual warfare as God leading us into battle, i.e. ‘God is on the move and Satan doesn’t like it’
prayer: Prayer. Father help me to have your perspective on spiritual warfare.
